summary: A federal judge ruled that prosecutors, led by Alexander R. Acosta, violated federal law by not informing victims about a non-prosecution agreement for Jeffrey Epstein. The ruling could nullify the agreement and allow for new federal charges against Epstein and his co-conspirators. The case has garnered renewed attention in the MeToo era, prompting investigations into prosecutorial misconduct.

persons.name: Alexander R. Acosta
persons.context: Acosta was the U.S. attorney in Miami at the time the non-prosecution agreement for Epstein was negotiated and is implicated in the failure to inform victims.

persons.name: Jeffrey E. Epstein
persons.context: Epstein is a wealthy financier accused of molesting underage girls and was the subject of the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Judge Kenneth A. Marra
persons.context: Judge Marra ruled that the prosecutors violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not informing victims about the non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Scarola represents the two victims who challenged the non-prosecution agreement and commented on the implications of the ruling.

persons.name: Bradley J. Edwards
persons.context: Edwards settled a separate lawsuit against Epstein and is involved in the current case based on the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Senator Sasse requested an investigation into the prosecutorial decisions regarding Epstein's case.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. attorney, was responsible for the prosecution decisions regarding Epstein.
Scarola represents the victims, including Jane Doe 1, in challenging the non-prosecution agreement.
Edwards is the lawyer for the victims, including Jane Doe 1, involved in the case against Epstein.
Senator Sasse's inquiry into the prosecutorial decisions involves Acosta's actions during the Epstein case.
